Author: imthahulk-09763
Review_Title: Good for scale and quite a bit of fun!
Review: Avengers Infinity War was based of the 1991 publication Infinity Gauntlet. In terms of scale, the movie was done well to translate to the big screen. There's no way it could have been done as it played out in the comics as the latter series of Infinity Gauntlet involved Marvel's comics entities(Eternity, Galacticus, The Watchers, The Celestials, etc...) and that would have been way too much. Although it would be very cool to have one or two show up in the final installment to say lend a helping hand and receive and introduction into the MCU. I've read other reviews where it stated that certain deaths lacked emotional punch as they were killed or eliminated only to have their deaths reversed in the final installment. Well, that's how it works in the comics. Death has way since been handled as temporary in both Marvel and DC comics. The other deaths that appeared to be more permanent were done well and I doubt those characters will resurface. There were some characters whose power sets seemed to get amped up quite a bit, i.e. Captain America while others seemed dialed down. Therefore, the way they were handled in battle made them seem a bit like some baby Hulks. And given how formidable Thanos would be with just one stone, the battle sequences were done well to provide the viewer with a sense of legitimacy. Because as shown in the comics, he could have easily defeated many of the characters in the movie with one or two stones, let alone five as he had when he arrived on Earth. I thought Thor's arc was handled well and he was finally given some scenes that actually provide some insight on his true power set and what he is capable of. So outside of the ignant mofos that sat behind and talked most of the movie, it was quite an enjoyable bit of escapism. Thanos was believable and given how much had to be played out in the movie, his character was well done with just enough character development to understand his motivation. The 2 hour 40 minute running time seems to fly by. It's pretty much 0-60 within the first 10 minutes of the movie. So give it a go. If you're a fan boy, you'll understand why much of the movie was shot and made the way it was. Those who don't read comics may have a harder time suspended their sense of belief. Titan was shown as more of a planet as opposed to a moon which it is. That Earthlings could survive on a moon of Saturn without some type of armor or space gear is beyond me. But maybe I'm nitpicking. Go check it out, you'll enjoy yourself.

Author: tidamadzikanda
Review_Title: I didn't know how to feel about the ending.........
Review:
Avengers: Infinity Wars, is an epic saga from the Marvel Cinematic Universe, as the Avengers rebel against the existential threat that is the overwhelming might of the supreme Thanos
The heroes of the narrative (Downey, Pratt, Johansson and the rest of the gang) are in excellent fighting form (as per usual) and bring undertones of organic humour (particularly Ruffalo and Holland) to balance the impending doom. 
Brolin's, Thanos is an infallible, and unmatched talent among previous Marvel Cinematic Universe villains. The leading antagonist (Brolin) could potentially challenge Heath Ledger's maniacal depiction of the Joker. This is not because Thanos is a megalomaniac and indomitable being, but his excellency lies rational. He is deft and absolute in both words and actions. He displays something inexplicably and hauntingly human about him. Thus, making him a fully realized anti-hero.
Alan Silvestri's beautiful layered soundtrack heightens the emotional intensity of the Avengers greatest threat to date. His ability to capture the constantly changing tone and as the inextricably linked narrative jumps from place to place is deserving of praise. 
The Russo's Infinity Wars (Part 1) is sure to become a pop culture reference of the future, as they have managed to achieve with the Thanos and the Avengers what Bryan Singer failed to do with Apocalypse (a character of banal platitude) and the X-Men. But we are left with our appetites unsated, and waiting with both repressed clamour and bated breath for the conclusion of the enthralling and dynamic journey in 2019.
-RJ

Review: This is the first MCU movie that I went to watch at the theatre.This long awaited movie created so much hype that even I could not resist the temptation of watching the endgame on a big screen.Being a long time marvel comics fan I was already well informed about the infinity gems(called infinity stones in the MCU) and of course The Mad Titan Thanos and his Black Order(named Children of Thanos in MCU).I am mentioning this not to brag my knowledge or something but because I felt that some scenes of the movie were really meant for the hardcore fans and my friend(not a hardcore comic fanatic himself) with whom I went to spectate this spectacle did not understand and enjoy some scenes to the extent I myself did.Anyway I would like to point out some pros and cons first.

Review: The movie overall was pretty good, but at times there were some plot holes and there were parts where I felt it was just too much. The beginning of the movie especially I found confusing as it started off with this heartbreaking moment that left audience members in shock and still trying to process what had happened. Then straight afterwards, it goes into a normal scene and we're already trying to make light of the situation with jokes in the movie. This, I didn't appreciate and because of it I missed about 20 minutes still trying to get over the first bit.

Author: berntronnberg
Review: I want to congratulate the producers, writers and directors for having the guts to give us an unpredictable ending. THANOS RULES! This is a fitting and respectable way to end the series and I hope the studio is able to resist any temptation to make more films. Definitely the best Avengers movie and hopefully the last. Don't get me wrong. I have loved the Avengers movies from the very beginning, but just like our lives and most probably the Universe (which will definitively happen much later than our insignificant planet is dead and gone) will come to an end one day, so should this series. And there's no more fitting way to do it than the way it was done in Infinity War, with Thanos sitting calm and relaxed, watching the horizon after a job well done. It was a tough job, but someone had to do it. And, as Thanos already hinted at the end of the movie Age of Ultron, the good old saying also applies to balancing the Universe. If you want something done well, you need to do it yourself. And boy did he do it well! I don't usually give a 10, but this was sheer perfection. Although, the 10 is conditional on the studio ending it here. Thanks again Marvel. This was true shock and awe!
